A complete remake of Half Life in the Source engine, it can't be bad. My only complaint is that it isn't as much a remake as it is a shiny new coat of paint. Valve was suprisingly lazy with this one, only adding slightly improved textures, ragdoll effect, water effects, and physics. While no doubt a good game, I would only say you should buy it if you don't own Half Life.

although many players experience bugs i believe this game is a good port. you can use console cheats if you stuck in somthing! to active anti-alising i use ignore application options in my driver settings then set it to 4x or higher.

The mouse glitches out when playing the game with the screen randomly flicking up and the mouse spazzing out in the middle. I am using a mac, so that might be why it is glitchy, but the mouse glitches makes this game not enjoyable.

If you own half-life then you have little reason to actually own this.
Now from the title you think this would be a remake in source right? just like counter-strike and day of defeat, but guess what? IT ISN'T.
What you get is nothing more than a port they didn't bother changing the graphics they just add water that looks better and make it shiny but in terms of gameplay they change very little so there is barely any point in getting it other than to get some maps in garry's mod and fuck around in them.
I'm addicted to this game

I first played Half Life 2, which was very entertaining.  When this was on sale for a couple dollars, I had to try it.  

It's a 'retro graphics' old 3d game, bud far more advanced than the original Doom game.  The aliens are genuinely scary, and the atmosphere becomes truly immersive.

The story and direction of the game has some gaps.  It makes it difficult to understand the objective in some levels.

The movement and control is not finite enough for me.  The player moves very fast at a sprint, and too slow at a walk.  Making careful jumps on ledges is difficult.  Ladders don't work right.  They 'push' the player away if not approached perfectly.  This results in many deaths from falling.


Overall, a good time.  Surprised to have easily spent nearly 20 hours to finish it!
One of my favorite games from my childhood!

HALF-LIFE: Source is HALF-LIFE, but in the Source engine. So you won't slide around as much when moving as you do in the original, the flashlight is more like the HALF-LIFE 2 flashlight, and there are rag doll effects. There will also be some HALF-LIFE 2 sounds, blood, and water effects. And there is a shine to most metal, especially the weapons, they are so shiny! So all that is nice, but there where a few problems too. Like the Barnacle tongues not hanging down all the way but still being able to grab you, music stopping when you enter a loading screen, and I felt like the final boss teleported you much more than the original. There where a few other minor problems, but I did still enjoy this. I think if you haven't played HALF-LIFE before I would still recommend the original, or keep in mind there are some problems with this. But if you have already played it (as you should) I would still recommend this just for the better movement and flashlight alone, and this is the version I will probably play in the future.

There's not alot too say about Half Life: Source. There's something about it that doesn't add up to what the original GldSrc edition had; whether it's the numerous bugs: including game breaking glitches like scientists getting killed when they shouldn't be, and guards not using retinal scanners. This ruined the overall experience for me, and i does not feel like an actual reboot of the game. Countless bugs aside, with the water reflections and effects of the source engine and ambient lighting mixed in with the original 90's models just makes the game feel.... ugly. The original game did not have stunning visuals (Which is understanderable since it came out in 1998) it felt good to play and with the same styled explosions and effects it all went together quite well. To any people looking to buy this game, keep in mind: This is NOT a remastered version, but just  a direct port to the source engine.

Well, that's all I have to say about the game. If you want to play Half Life, definately go for the original GldSrc release and not the source engine remake. If you want a complete remaster, go play Black Mesa. It's a fantastic remaster built in the source engine. With great lighting, voice acting, textures models etc, it's great. With a couple changes to maps here and there, it still stays true to what the original game had.
